{{About|the hand tool|the archaeology journal|Trowel (journal)}} {{Distinguish|Trowell}} {{refimprove|date=September 2014}}
[[File:Masons trowel.jpg|250px|thumb|[[Masonry trowel]]]]
A '''trowel''' is a small [[hand tool]] used for digging, applying, smoothing, or moving small amounts of viscous or particulate material. Common varieties include the [[masonry trowel]], garden trowel, and float trowel.
A [[power trowel]] is a much larger gasoline or electrically powered walk-behind device with rotating paddles used to finish concrete floors.
==Hand tool== [[File:Trowel.JPG|thumb|200px|right|Garden trowel]] [[File:Foundation trowel.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Ceremonial bricklayer's trowel used in laying one of the foundation stones of the commencement column of the Federal Capital city of [[Canberra]] in 1913]] [[File:TrowelPS.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Pointing trowel used in an archaeological excavation]]
Numerous forms of trowel are used in [[masonry]], [[concrete]], and [[drywall]] construction, as well as applying adhesives such as those used in tiling and laying synthetic flooring. [[Masonry trowel]]s are traditionally made of [[forged]] [[carbon steel]], but some newer versions are made of cast [[stainless steel]],{{cn|date=February 2017}} which has longer wear and is rust-free. These include:
*'''Bricklayer's trowel''' has an elongated triangular-shaped flat metal blade, used by [[stonemason|masons]] for leveling, spreading, and shaping [[cement]], [[plaster]], and [[mortar (masonry)|mortar]].
*'''Pointing trowel''', a scaled-down version of a bricklayer's trowel, for small jobs and repair work.
*'''Tuck pointing trowel''' is long and thin, designed for packing mortar between bricks.
*'''Float trowel''' or '''finishing trowel''' is usually rectangular, used to smooth, level, or texture the top layer of hardening concrete. A '''flooring trowel''' has one rectangular end and one pointed end, made to fit corners. A '''grout float''' is used for applying and working [[grout]] into gaps in floor and wall tile.
*'''Gauging trowel''' has a rounded tip, used to mix measured proportions of the different ingredients for quick set [[plaster]].
*'''Pool trowel''' is a flat-bladed tool with rounded ends used to apply coatings to concrete, especially on [[swimming pool]] decks.
*'''Margin trowel''' is a small rectangular bladed tool used to move, apply, and smooth small amounts of masonry or adhesive material.
[[File:US Navy 050705-N-1261P-025 Builder Constructionman Guthrie Kees and Utilitiesman 3rd Class Robert Jones use trowels to smooth freshly poured concrete for a new dispatch office.jpg|thumb|upright|US Navy personnel using float trowels to smooth freshly poured concrete]]
*'''Notched trowel''' is a rectangular shaped tool with regularly spaced notches along one or more sides used to apply adhesive when adhering tile, or laying synthetic floor surfaces.
Other forms of trowel include:
*'''[[gardening|Garden]] trowel''', a tool with a pointed, scoop-shaped metal [[blade]] and wooden, metal, or plastic handle. It is used for breaking up earth, digging small holes, especially for [[planting]] and [[weeding]], mixing in [[fertilizer]] or other additives, and transferring plants to [[container gardening|pots]].
*'''[[Cathole]] trowel''' is used for burying personal waste in the [[backcountry]]. They are often made of lighter weight materials than gardening trowels to make them easier to carry. Also, they may have features such as [[ruler|ruled]] sides to measure for proper cathole depth or jagged edges for cutting through roots or frozen soil. Some cathole trowels are also designed to fold-up or collapse into a smaller size for easier storage. Others allow for items such as toilet paper to be stored inside the handle.<ref name="Straight Up On The Rocks">{{cite web |url=http://straightupontherocks.co.uk/posts/174/camping-trowels-equipment-spotlight |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808042848/http://straightupontherocks.co.uk/posts/174/camping-trowels-equipment-spotlight |archivedate=2014-08-08 |df= }} Camping Trowels - Equipment Spotlight</ref>
*In '''[[archaeology]]''' brick or pointing trowels (usually 4" or 5" steel trowels) are used to scratch the strata in an [[Excavation (archaeology)|excavation]] and allow the colours of the soil to be clear, so that the different strata can be identified, processed and excavated. In the [[United States]], there are several preferred brands of pointing trowels, including the [[Marshalltown trowel]]; while in the [[British Isles]] the [[William Hunt and Sons|WHS 4" pointing trowel]] is the traditional tool.
==See also== * [[Taping knife]], a drywall tool with a wide blade for spreading joint compound * [[Putty knife]], a generally smaller and variously shaped tool used in a variety of applications * [[Palette knife]], a smaller but similarly shaped tool used in oil painting
== References == {{reflist}}
{{commonscat|Trowels}} {{Wiktionary}} {{Garden tools}}
[[Category:Mechanical hand tools]] [[Category:Gardening tools]] [[Category:Plastering]]

{{Infobox building | name = Waste House | status = complete | image = Waste House, University of Brighton, Grand Parade, Brighton (September 2015) (17).JPG | image_alt = | caption = The building from the south-southeast | map_type = United Kingdom Brighton | map_alt = | map_caption = Location in central [[Brighton]] | altitude = | building_type = | architectural_style = [[Contemporary architecture|Contemporary]] ([[Sustainable architecture|Sustainable]]) | cost = £140,000 | owner = [[University of Brighton]] | landlord = | location = | address = [[University of Brighton Faculty of Arts]], 58–67 Grand Parade, [[Brighton]] BN2 0JY | location_town = [[Brighton and Hove]] | location_country = United Kingdom | coordinates = {{coord|50.823547|-0.134809|display=inline,title}} | groundbreaking_date = 26 November 2012 | start_date = May 2013 | completion_date = April 2014 | opening_date = 10 June 2014 | floor_count = 2 | main_contractor = [[Mears Group]] | architect = Duncan Baker-Brown | architecture_firm = BBM Sustainable Design | references = <ref name="BHN-42246">{{cite news|url=http://www.brightonandhovenews.org/2015/09/14/waste-house-in-brighton-shortlisted-for-stephen-lawrence-prize/42246|title=Waste House in Brighton shortlisted for Stephen Lawrence Prize|last=le Duc|first=Frank|date=14 September 2015|publisher=Brighton & Hove News|accessdate=15 September 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bZF7peXT|archivedate=15 September 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="Guardian">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2014/jul/07/future-housing-rubbish-architecture-waste-sustainable-homes|title=The house that 20,000 toothbrushes built|last=Wainwright|first=Oliver|date=7 July 2014|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group|Guardian News and Media Ltd]]|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=15 September 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bZF7u6uu|archivedate=15 September 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="BUA&H">{{cite web|url=http://arts.brighton.ac.uk/business-and-community/the-house-that-kevin-built|title=Brighton 'Waste House'|publisher=[[University of Brighton Faculty of Arts]]|year=2014|accessdate=15 September 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bZF7xfyW|archivedate=15 September 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="Dezeen">{{cite web|url=http://www.dezeen.com/2014/06/19/waste-house-by-bbm-architects-is-uks-first-permanent-building-made-from-rubbish/|title=Waste House by BBM is "UK's first permanent building made from rubbish"|publisher=Dezeen Ltd|date=19 June 2014|accessdate=15 September 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bZF8D9KW|archivedate=15 September 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="Mears">{{cite web|url=http://www.mearsgroup.co.uk/work-starts-on-the-house-made-from-waste/|title=Work starts on the house made from waste|date=26 November 2012|publisher=[[Mears Group]] plc|accessdate=15 September 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bZFEOcpY|archivedate=15 September 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="AJ">{{cite web|url=http://www.architectsjournal.co.uk/buildings/brighton-waste-house/8666191.article|title=Brighton Waste House|date=28 July 2014|last=Hartman|first=Hattie|publisher=[[Emap|EMAP Publishing Ltd Co.]]|work=[[Architects' Journal]]|accessdate=15 September 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bZFERDHW|archivedate=15 September 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="ASME">{{cite web|url=https://www.asme.org/engineering-topics/articles/sustainability/waste-house-example-sustainable-building|title="Waste House" an Example of Sustainable Building|date=November 2014|last=Pero|first=James|publisher=[[ASME|American Society of Mechanical Engineers]]|accessdate=15 September 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bZFPAA0C|archivedate=15 September 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref> }} '''Waste House''' is a building on the [[University of Brighton]] campus in the centre of [[Brighton]] on the south coast of England. It was built between 2012 and 2014 as a project involving hundreds of students and apprentices and was designed by Duncan Baker-Brown, an architect who also lectures at the university. The materials consist of a wide range of construction industry and household waste—from toothbrushes and old jeans to VHS cassettes and bicycle inner tubes—and it is the first public building in Europe to be built primarily of such products. "From a distance [resembling] an ordinary contemporary [[Townhouse|town house]]",<ref name="BBM-WH">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbm-architects.co.uk/index.php/waste-house|title=Waste House, Grand Parade Campus, Brighton University|year=2015|publisher=BBM Sustainable Design|accessdate=15 September 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bZFEvQPZ|archivedate=15 September 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref> Waste House is designed to be low-energy and sustainable, and will be in continuous use as a test-bed for the university's design, architecture and engineering students. The building has won several awards and was shortlisted for the [[Royal Institute of British Architects]]' Stephen Lawrence Prize in September 2015.
==Background== Waste House has its origins in an earlier project by Duncan Baker-Brown,<ref name="BUA&H-Team"/> a senior lecturer at the university and a director of architecture firm BBM Sustainable Design<ref name="BUA&H-Team"/> based at [[Cooksbridge railway station]] in East Sussex.<ref name="BBM-Contact">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbm-architects.co.uk/index.php/contact/contact-us|title=Contact BBM|year=2015|publisher=BBM Sustainable Design|accessdate=15 September 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bZFEqqCF|archivedate=15 September 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref> On [[Channel 4]] television programme ''The House That Kevin Built'' (2008), he and designer and television presenter [[Kevin McCloud]] assembled a "low-energy ... ecologically friendly" [[Prefabricated home|prefabricated house]] made of organic materials. It was the first such building to be constructed in the United Kingdom.<ref name="BUA&H-Team"/><ref name="Mail-2684545">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-2684565/The-house-junk-built-4-000-VHS-cassettes-two-tons-jeans-20-000-toothbrushes-used-build-Brightons-eco-friendly-home.html|title=The house that junk built: 4,000 VHS cassettes, two tons of jeans and 20,000 toothbrushes used to build Brighton's eco-friendly home|date=8 July 2014|publisher=[[DMG Media|Associated Newspapers Ltd]]|work=[[Daily Mail]]|accessdate=15 September 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bZFP3f15|archivedate=15 September 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="BBC-20503267">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-sussex-20503267|title=Brighton university recreates designer's rubbish house|date=26 November 2012|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=15 September 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bZFOzAnV|archivedate=15 September 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref> Baker-Brown was responsible for the design of this building, which was in turn referred to as "The House that Kevin Built".<ref name="ASME"/> Originally Baker-Brown planned simply to take down the building and re-erect it at the University.<ref name="ASME"/> Instead, the temporary building formed the prototype for Waste House, and since 2008 work has been undertaken at the [[University of Brighton Faculty of Arts]] to develop the ideas and techniques used on the programme in order to build a permanent house which can be used to test materials, construction theories and new techniques.<ref name="BUA&H-About">{{cite web|url=http://arts.brighton.ac.uk/business-and-community/the-house-that-kevin-built/about|title=About|publisher=[[University of Brighton Faculty of Arts]]|date=August 2014|accessdate=16 September 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6baq0XSRk|archivedate=16 September 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref> It is intended to be "a real live research project"<ref name="ASME"/> as well as a building which the university and other groups can use.<ref name="BUA&H-About"/><ref name="TreeHugger"/>
==Design and construction== Work was planned to begin in 2012 in time for an end-of-year completion date and a public opening in February 2013.<ref name="BUA&H-About"/> These dates were not achieved, but preparation started on 26 November 2012<ref name="Mears"/> and by May 2013 construction was underway.<ref name="Dezeen"/><ref name="BUA&H-Team">{{cite web|url=http://arts.brighton.ac.uk/ease/wastehouse/about/the-team|title=The Team|publisher=[[University of Brighton Faculty of Arts]]|year=2014|accessdate=15 September 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bZFEl1YD|archivedate=15 September 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref> Work finished in April 2014, the building was featured as part of the [[Brighton Festival]] the following month,<ref name="Dezeen"/> the public were able to view the interior during June 2014,<ref name="Mail-2684545"/> and by August 2014 Waste House was complete.<ref name="BUA&H-About"/> Construction cost £140,000<ref name="AJ"/> and the total value of the contract was £200,000.<ref name="RIBA-SE-Award">{{cite web|url=http://www.ribaj.com/buildings/brighton-waste-house-brighton|title=Brighton Waste House, Brighton|date=24 April 2015|publisher=[[Royal Institute of British Architects]]|work=[[RIBA Journal]]|accessdate=15 September 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bZFPMtZX|archivedate=15 September 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref> Waste House is the first permanent public building in Europe made from waste material.<ref name="BHN-42246"/><ref name="BUA&H"/>
Over 300 students from the University of Brighton, [[City College Brighton & Hove]] (CCB) and apprentices from housing provider [[Mears Group]] were involved in the project.<ref name="BHN-42246"/> The construction work was mainly undertaken by CCB students, the Mears apprentices and some volunteers,<ref name="Dezeen"/> led by a project manager from Mears Group.<ref name="BUA&H-Team"/> Students learning carpentry at CCB designed the timber-framed structure and the "fine timber staircase, finished with a decorative flourish of offcuts".<ref name="Guardian"/> Many of the structural elements were created in the college's own workshops. University of Brighton Faculty of Arts students worked with Baker-Brown on the design, the selection of materials and on interior features such as furniture. Overall, 97.5% of the time taken to build Waste House—2,507 [[Man-hour|person-days]]—was provided by students and volunteers,<ref name="Dezeen"/> and about 700 people worked on the project.<ref name="BUA&H-Team"/> A major aim of the project was to introduce students and apprentices to sustainable building techniques and to allow them to continue testing their ideas by [[retrofitting]] new fixtures.<ref name="Mears"/>
==Materials== The purpose of building Waste House was to demonstrate that material considered to be waste, and therefore destined for [[landfill]], could be used to create a viable permanent building. Baker-Brown stated that in the United Kingdom, 20% of construction materials go to waste—so the equivalent of one house worth of unwanted material is generated for every five houses built.<ref name="BHN-42246"/><ref name="Guardian"/> Between 85%<ref name="BUA&H"/> and 90%<ref name="BHN-42246"/> of the materials used in Waste House are building waste of this type or ordinary household and consumer products which are no longer needed.<ref name="BUA&H-About"/>
[[File:Waste House, University of Brighton, Grand Parade, Brighton (September 2015) (7).JPG|thumb|left|The building is clad with carpet tiles laid with their [[underlay]] facing out.]] Structurally, the building is [[Timber framing|timber-framed]]<ref name="DuPont">{{cite web|url=http://www.dupont.co.uk/products-and-services/construction-materials/tyvek-building-envelope/case-studies/waste-house-brighton.html|title=DuPont™ Tyvek® advanced breather membranes help waste products to perform in unexpected ways in a new building experiment|year=2015|publisher=[[DuPont]]|accessdate=15 September 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bZFP7dYc|archivedate=15 September 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref> and uses a mixture of reclaimed wood and [[plywood]] from various sources around Brighton. It has been constructed on foundations of [[ground granulated blast-furnace slag]].<ref name="Dezeen"/><ref name="TreeHugger">{{cite web|url=http://www.treehugger.com/green-architecture/university-brighton-waste-house-built-with-85-percent-junk.html|title=Built with 85% junk, Waste House will be university's "living laboratory" (Video)|last=Mok|first=Kimberley|date=25 June 2014|publisher=[[Mother Nature Network|MNN Holding Company, LLC]]|work=TreeHugger|accessdate=15 September 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bZFP1McG|archivedate=15 September 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref> The "rather unusual"<ref name="DuPont"/> walls consist of a mixture of waste chalk and clay left over or reclaimed from building sites.<ref name="Mail-2684545"/><ref name="DuPont"/> These are compressed into [[rammed earth]]-style walls using pneumatic equipment—a technique which improves the building's energy conservation, because such walls store [[solar energy]] for a long time.<ref name="BUA&H-About"/> On the outside the walls are covered with "a scaly surface of rubbery black shingles"—2,000 carpet tiles from an old office building in Brighton. Their fire-retardant, waterproof underlay faces outwards, providing weatherproof cladding and insulation.<ref name="Guardian"/><ref name="Dezeen"/> Their mostly black appearance is varied in places by being laminated with plastic bags in various colours.<ref name="ASME"/> Between the carpet tiles and the walls themselves, some new material was used: [[DuPont]] supplied about {{convert|400|sqm|sqft}} of "breathable membrane", to further weatherproof the building, and "Housewrap" moisture seal.<ref name="DuPont"/> Inside, the walls are laid with reclaimed plasterboard coated with surplus paint from construction sites.<ref name="Guardian"/> The main [[load-bearing wall]] is formed of 10 tonnes of compressed chalk spoil from a building site nearby.<ref name="Dezeen"/> Throughout the building, the space between the boarding and the exterior clay and chalk blocks has been filled with household rubbish which will act as insulation. Sensors have been installed to monitor how well heat is kept in,<ref name="Dezeen"/> which will form part of a [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] project for a University of Brighton student.<ref name="BUA&H-About"/><ref name="ASME"/> The insulation materials are revealed in various places by "little peephole windows"<ref name="Guardian"/> (transparent panels in the walls):<ref name="Dezeen"/> as well as some secondhand conventional ([[polyurethane]]) insulation material,<ref name="Guardian"/> there are floppy disks, 4,000 VHS cassettes, 4,000 DVD and video cases, two tonnes of denim offcuts from pairs of jeans and denim jackets, cycle inner tubes to insulate windows, and 20,000 toothbrushes.<ref name="Guardian"/><ref name="Dezeen"/> The cassettes and other media came from the stock of rental shops which were closing down; an aeroplane cleaning company at nearby [[Gatwick Airport]] donated most of the toothbrushes, which were provided to First and Business Class passengers and discarded after one use,<ref name="BUA&H-About"/><ref name="Mail-2684545"/> and some others were provided by Brighton schoolchildren; and the denim came from textile traders<ref name="Dezeen"/><ref name="Guardian"/><ref name="ASME"/> (in particular, one company which turned imported jeans into denim shorts by cutting off the legs).<ref name="Guardian"/>
Many materials were obtained on the [[Freegle]] website—a free reuse and recycling service developed from [[The Freecycle Network]].<ref name="Guardian"/> These include the clay tiles on the roof,<ref name="Guardian"/> the kitchen<ref name="Dezeen"/> and some of the insulation material.<ref name="ASME"/> Cat Fletcher, one of the founders of Freegle UK, was part of the Waste House project team<ref name="BUA&H-Team"/> and was responsible for obtaining many of the materials, both from Freegle members (numbering 18,000 in the Brighton area) and from other sources.<ref name="Argus-12910839"/><ref name="2DN">{{cite web|url=https://www.2degreesnetwork.com/groups/2degrees-community/resources/how-can-20000-old-toothbrushes-be-used-insulate-house-brightons-waste-house-explains-all/|title=How can 20,000 old toothbrushes be used to insulate a house? Brighton’s Waste House explains all|last=Baker-Brown|first=Duncan|date=5 March 2014|publisher=2degrees Ltd|accessdate=15 September 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bZFP5rtY|archivedate=15 September 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref> Other than the specialist cladding materials supplied by DuPont, the only new products used in the building are the triple-glazed windows and the material used in the wiring and plumbing.<ref name="Guardian"/>
==Awards and reception== In September 2015, Waste House was nominated for that year's Stephen Lawrence Prize. This [[Royal Institute of British Architects]] (RIBA) award, named after the aspiring architect who was [[Murder of Stephen Lawrence|murdered in 1993]], is for projects with a budget of up to £1 million. In its shortlisting for the award, which was judged in mid-October 2015, judges from the RIBA stated that the house "has sufficient scientific integrity to be taken seriously by the construction industry" and the potential to alter political attitudes to recycling.<ref name="BHN-42246"/> Waste House was one of seven buildings nominated for the prize, which was won by a fishing hut designed by [[Niall McLaughlin Architects]].<ref name="SLP">{{cite web|url=https://www.architecture.com/StirlingPrize/Awards2015/StephenLawrencePrize/RIBAStephenLawrencePrize2015.aspx|title=Stephen Lawrence Prize 2015|publisher=[[Royal Institute of British Architects]]|year=2016|accessdate=23 March 2016|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6gETSpdYB|archivedate=23 March 2016|deadurl=no}}</ref>
Waste House was one of several buildings in Sussex, along with the [[Chichester Festival Theatre]] and [[St Botolph's Church, Botolphs|St Botolph's Church]] at [[Botolphs]], to win an award at the RIBA South East Regional Awards in April 2015. It was described as "a project with an interesting agenda" and "a collective of experiments in which students learn by application".<ref name="Argus-12910839">{{cite news|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/12910839.Waste_house_given_a_top_design_gong/|title=Waste house given a top design gong|last=James|first=Ben|date=24 April 2015|publisher=[[Newsquest|Newsquest Media (Southern) Ltd]]|work=[[The Argus (Brighton)|The Argus]]|accessdate=15 September 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bZFPDeEP|archivedate=15 September 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref> Duncan Baker-Brown also won an Argus Achievement Award from local newspaper ''[[The Argus (Brighton)|The Argus]]''.<ref name="Argus-12910839"/>
RIBA awarded Waste House a Sustainability Award in 2014.<ref name="Argus-12910839"/> It described "some of the experiments [as] extraordinary", commenting specifically on the toothbrush insulation and the vinyl banner vapour control layers, and noted that "the continually evolving [design] brief" would "continue to question important issues of recycling that affect everyone".<ref name="RIBA-SE-Award"/>
The 2Degrees Network, a worldwide collaborative association of [[sustainable business]]es,<ref name="2DN-About">{{cite web|url=https://www.2degreesnetwork.com/about/|title=Our Story|year=2015|publisher=2degrees Ltd|accessdate=16 September 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6baq4lhDo|archivedate=16 September 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref> awarded the building a Champions Award in 2014. Waste House was described as "an investment in educating the next generation of designers and builders to think and build more sustainably".<ref name="2DN"/>
In view of its low energy use, Waste House has a [[building energy rating]] of A.<ref name="BUA&H"/> When work started, Baker-Brown stated the aim of making it one of the United Kingdom's first A*-rated buildings.<ref name="Mears"/><ref name="BBC-20503267"/>
==See also== *[[Buildings and architecture of Brighton and Hove]] *[[Sustainable architecture]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *{{commons category inline|Waste House, Brighton}}
{{Brighton and Hove buildings}}

{{Unreferenced|date=June 2011}}
'''Well integrity''', in regard to [[oil well]]s, is defined by [http://www.standard.no/en/sectors/energi-og-klima/petroleum/norsok-standard-categories/d-drilling/d-0104/ NORSOK D-010] as the "“Application of technical, operational and organizational solutions to reduce risk of uncontrolled release of formation fluids throughout the life cycle of a well”. There are various facets to well integrity, including accountability/responsibility, well operating processes, well service processes, tubing/annulus integrity, tree/wellhead integrity and testing of safety systems.
==Accountability/responsibility== Accountability is the position that ensures a particular task is being done. They typically control the budget and [[organizational chart]] structure.
Responsibility is the position that actually does the task. There are a variety of tasks associated with well integrity and responsibility can reside with a field's [[Well services|well operations engineer]], operators, well service technicians, etc.
==Well operating processes== This includes processes such as personnel competency, well startup-operating-shutdown procedures, process to report anomalies, corrosion/erosion control, etc.
==Well service processes== This includes processes such as personnel competency, intervention procedures, etc.
==Tubing/annulus integrity== This refers to the integrity of the [[production tubing]]. Common threats to tubing integrity are erosion and corrosion by production fluids, which denude the steel. The other threat is pressure differential between the tubing and the 'A' annulus. If it exceeds the rated pressure of the tubing, there is a risk of tubing burst or tubing collapse.
This refers to the integrity of the [[Casing (oil well)|casing strings]], which bound the [[Annulus (oil well)|annuli]]. All annuli will naturally be filled to some level with brine or other fluids from the completion, though the 'A' annulus may have gas down to the lowest gas lift valve if the well is [[gas lift]]ed. The major integrity issues comes from the differential pressure across the casings due to the weight of brine on either side. To protect well integrity, each annulus will have a [[MAASP|Maximum Allowable Annulus Surface Pressure]].
==Tree and wellhead integrity== This refers to the integrity of the surface (or [[subsea]]) equipment. The [[wellhead]] and the [[Christmas tree (oil well)|tree]] are typically suitably engineered to be able to withstand the normal operating pressures. The major integrity issues for these components surround the operation of the valves, which are prone to leaking. For this reason, valves must be routinely maintained.
==Testing of safety systems== This refers to testing of surface and subsurface safety systems.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Well Integrity}} [[Category:Oil wells]]

revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox website | name = ZDNet | logo = [[File:ZDNet_Logo.png|120px]] | logocaption = | screenshot = | caption = | url = {{URL|www.zdnet.com}} | commercial = | type = [[Business]] [[Technology]] | registration = Optional | language = English | num_users = 36 million monthly<ref name="Wolfram Alpha">{{cite web|url= https://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=monthly+visitors+zdnet.com |title = Monthly visitors to zdnet.com | publisher= [[Wolfram Alpha]] via [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2017-10-07 }}</ref> | owner = [[CBS Interactive]] | editor = Larry Dignan | launch_date = {{Start date and age|1991|04|01}} | alexa = {{Decrease}} 3,279 ({{as of|2017|10|07|alt=October 2017}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/www.zdnet.com |title= zdnet.com Site Overview | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2017-10-07 }}</ref> }}
'''ZDNet''' is a business technology news website published by [[CBS Interactive]], along with [[TechRepublic]]. The brand was founded on April 1, 1991, as a general interest technology portal from [[Ziff Davis]] and evolved into an enterprise IT-focused online publication owned by [[CNET Networks]].
==History==
===Beginnings: 1991 to 1995===
ZDNet began as a subscription-based digital service called "ZiffNet" that offered computing information to users of CompuServe. It featured computer industry forums, events, features and searchable archives.
Initially, ZiffNet was intended to serve as a common place to find content from all [[Ziff-Davis]] print publications. As such, ZiffNet was an expansion on an earlier online service called PCMagNet for readers of [[PC Magazine]]. Launched in 1988, PCMagNet in turn was the evolution of Ziff Davis' first electronic publishing venture, a bulletin board, which launched in 1985.<ref name="Ziff-Davis">{{Cite web | title = ZDNet celebrates five years of success in subscription online services | work = | publisher = Ziff-Davis | date = 1 April 1996 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/ZD+NET+CELEBRATES+FIVE+YEARS+OF+SUCCESS+IN+SUBSCRIPTION+ONLINE...-a018143807 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}}</ref>
On June 20, 1995, Ziff-Davis announced the consolidation of its online information services under a single name, "ZD Net." The service had grown its membership to 275,000 subscribers across six platforms: CompuServe, Prodigy, AT&T Interchange, the Microsoft Network, AppleLink and eWorld.<ref name="thefreelibrary.com">{{Cite web | title = ZIFF-DAVIS unifies its online services under a new name: ZDNet | work = | publisher = Ziff-Davis | date = 20 June 1995 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/ZIFF-DAVIS+UNIFIES+ITS+ONLINE+SERVICES+UNDER+A+NEW+NAME%3a+ZD+NET-a017072062 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}}</ref>
A few months prior to the name consolidation, Ziff-Davis expanded onto the World Wide Web under the name "ZD Net."<ref>{{Cite web | title = ZIFF-DAVIS offers advertisers space on world wide web; Charter marketers include Oracle and Gateway 2000 | work = | publisher = Ziff-Davis | date = 29 March 1995 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/ZIFF-DAVIS+OFFERS+ADVERTISERS+SPACE+ON+WORLD+WIDE+WEB%3b+CHARTER...-a016731794 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref> [[Dan Farber]], former editor-in-chief of ''[[PC Week]]'' and ''[[MacWeek]]'', was named editor-in-chief of the property.<ref>{{Cite web | title = ZIFF-DAVIS announces promotion of Dan Farber to vice president and editor-in-chief of ZDNet | work = | publisher = Ziff-Davis | date = 2 May 1996 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/ZIFF-DAVIS+ANNOUNCES+PROMOTION+OF+DAN+FARBER+TO+VICE+PRESIDENT+AND...-a018245012 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref> By June, the site was recording web traffic of 2.5 million pageviews per week.<ref name="thefreelibrary.com"/>
===Early history: 1995 to 2000===
By its fifth anniversary in 1996, the collective "ZD Net" brand—now on the Web, America Online, Microsoft Network and Prodigy—counted 300,000 subscribers and was named the second-highest grossing advertising site on the Web.<ref name="Ziff-Davis"/> The site also expanded overseas: initially to France, Germany and the U.K.; later to China, Australia, Hong Kong, Italy, Korea, Malaysia, Russia, Spain, Taiwan and India.<ref>{{Cite web | title = Ziff-Davis Announces The Launch of 10 New, International Editions of ZDNet | work = | publisher = Ziff-Davis | date = 15 January 1997 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Ziff-Davis+Announces+The+Launch+of+10+New%2c+International+Editions+of...-a019028513 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref>
In 1997, the website—now the brand's flagship property—underwent another redesign that featured topical "channels" of content. It also marked the change in name from "ZD Net" to "ZDNet."<ref>{{Cite web | title = ZDNet Unveils Innovative Web Site Design at Internet World '97; Delivers Wealth of Content Through Distinct Topic 'Channels' | work = | publisher = Ziff-Davis | date = 12 March 1997 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/ZDNet+Unveils+Innovative+Web+Site+Design+at+Internet+World+'97%3b...-a019197892 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref>
====ZDNet News====
Two months prior, the company launched ZDNet News, or "ZDNN," the site's first dedicated section to original reportage.<ref>{{Cite web | title = ZD Net Launches ZD Net News, Breaks the Mold of News-Oriented Web Sites | work = | publisher = Ziff-Davis | date = 19 November 1996 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/ZD+Net+Launches+ZD+Net+News%2c+Breaks+the+Mold+of+News-Oriented+Web...-a018871663 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref> Among the journalists hired to staff the department were former [[Computer Shopper (US magazine)|Computer Shopper]] executive editor Charlie Cooper, [[San Jose Mercury News]] business editor Steve Hamm, PC Week Inside senior editor Bill Snyder, PC Week editor [[John Dodge (editor)|John Dodge]], [[Computerworld]] editor Michael Fitzgerald and PC Week editorial director [[Jim Louderback]].<ref>{{Cite web | title = ZDNet Unveils Enhanced ZDNet News Web Site: the Number One Source for News on the Digital Revolution | work = | publisher = Ziff-Davis | date = 19 November 1996 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/ZDNet+Unveils+Enhanced+ZDNet+News+Web+Site%3a+the+Number+One+Source+for...-a019353021 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref>
The appointment of digital publishing executive [[Dan Rosensweig]] as ZDNet's first president capped a year of significant change for the brand.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/cheggcom-names-daniel-rosensweig-as-president-and-chief-executive-officer-83367592.html|title=Chegg.com Names Daniel Rosensweig as President and Chief Executive Officer |accessdate=2010-02-02}}</ref>
In 1998, ZDNet launched "Inter@active Investor," or ZDII, a spin-off website for investors that offered financial news and information on technology companies.<ref>{{Cite web | title = ZDNet Introduces Inter@ctive Investor, Web's Most Comprehensive Source of Financial News and Information on Tech Companies | work = | publisher = Ziff-Davis | date = 2 February 1998 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/ZDNet+Introduces+Inter%40ctive+Investor%2c+Web's+Most+Comprehensive...-a020209600 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref>
====ZDTV====
On May 11, 1998, Ziff-Davis launched ZDTV as the first cable television channel and website to offer 24-hour programming about computing and the Internet. The venture, which was partly owned by Vulcan Enterprises, was supported with a staff of 170 and incorporated ZDNet content on its website, ZDTV.com.<ref>{{Cite web | title = ZDTV Goes Live From its San Francisco Studios | work = | publisher = Ziff-Davis | date = 11 May 1998 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/ZDTV+Goes+Live+From+its+San+Francisco+Studios-a020581907 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref><ref>{{Cite web | last = Krigel | first = Beth Lipton | authorlink = | title = ZDTV starts broadcasting | work = | publisher = CNET | date = 11 May 1998 | url = http://news.cnet.com/2100-1023-211074.html | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref> The channel would later become [[Tech TV]].
By the end of 1998, ZDNet was the dominant technology brand online. It led its closest rival, CNET, by a 26 percent margin and was the 13th most popular site on the Web, reaching 8.4 million users, or 13.4 percent of all users on the Web.<ref>{{Cite web | title = 13 Percent of All Web Users Visited ZDNet in October. | work = | publisher = Ziff-Davis | date = 30 November 1998 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/13+Percent+of+All+Web+Users+Visited+ZDNet+in+October.-a053275589 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref> The site would reach an additional 600,000 users within a year.<ref>{{Cite web | title = ZDNet Sites Reach Traffic Milestones: 9 Million Visitors, or Nearly 15 Percent of All Web Users in March. | work = | publisher = Ziff-Davis | date = 27 April 1999 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/ZDNet+Sites+Reach+Traffic+Milestones%3a+9+Million+Visitors%2c+or+Nearly...-a054478080 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref>
====ZDNet the company====
In 1999, Ziff-Davis spun ZDNet off as a separate company and offered it as a tracking stock, ZDZ, to accompany the parent stock, ZD. An initial public offering raised $190 million, but the tracking stock was eliminated in early 2000 and revived as common stock.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web |url=http://ecommerce.hostip.info/pages/1117/Ziff-Davis-Inc-COMPUTER-TECHNICAL-PORTAL-ZDNET.html|title=Inc Ziff-Davis – Computer And Technical Portal, Zdnet}}</ref> The new company soon acquired Updates.com, a software upgrade service. It was incorporated into the site's "Help Channel."<ref>{{Cite web | title = ZDNet to Acquire Updates.com. | work = | publisher = Ziff-Davis | date = 7 June 1999 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/ZDNet+to+Acquire+Updates.com.-a054806640 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref>
====Consumer expansion====
In 1999, ZDNet also launched "Tech Life," a network of six consumer-focused tech sites intended to attract parents ("FamilyPC"), music listeners ("ZDNet Music"), gadget enthusiasts ("ZDNet Equip"), gamers ("ZDNet [[GameSpot]]") and basic users ("Internet Life" with Yahoo).
It also launched "Computer Stew," a web-based comedy show about technology that featured John Hargrave and Jay Stevens,<ref>{{Cite web | title = ZDNet Launches 'Tech Life' Consumer Channel "A guidepost at the crossroads of technology and your life". | work = | publisher = Ziff-Davis | date = 25 October 1999 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/ZDNet+Launches+'Tech+Life'+Consumer+Channel+%22A+guidepost+at+the...-a056888268 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref> as well as the first ZDNet Holiday Gift Guide.
On December 30, 1999, ZDNet launched a $25 million branding campaign in response to a $100 million advertising campaign launched by rival CNET.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
ZDNet's lead over the competition narrowed by 2000. Despite a record 10.7 million unique users in January, it managed only a 13 percent lead over the next competitor.<ref>{{Cite web | title = ZDNet Sites Becomes First Technology Content Property to Surpass 10 Million Unique Monthly Visitor Milestone. | work = | publisher = Ziff-Davis | date = 7 April 2000 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/ZDNet+Sites+Becomes+First+Technology+Content+Property+to+Surpass+10...-a061381948 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref> By mid-2000, ZDNet had expanded to 23 countries in 14 languages on six continents.<ref>{{Cite web | title = ZDNet GameSpot Creates Ultimate Gaming Destination. | work = | publisher = Ziff-Davis | date = 10 May 2000 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/ZDNet+GameSpot+Creates+Ultimate+Gaming+Destination.-a061992987 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref>
===The CNET years: 2000 to 2007===
On July 19, 2000, CNET Networks—parent company of CNET, ZDNet's largest rival—announced that it would acquire ZDNet for about $1.6 billion.<ref>{{Cite web | title = CNET Networks, Inc. Acquires ZDNet to Create the World's Leading Platform For Buyers, Sellers and Suppliers of Technology Products and Services. | work = | publisher = CNET Networks | date = 19 July 2000 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/CNET+Networks%2c+Inc.+Acquires+ZDNet+to+Create+the+World's+Leading...-a063555054 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref> Some analysts thought that the merger of CNET and ZDNet would lead to redundancy in their product offerings, but research revealed that their target audiences had just 25 percent overlap.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/07/20/business/cnet-is-buying-what-remains-of-ziff-davis.html|title=CNET Is Buying What Remains Of Ziff-Davis |accessdate=2017-11-14 | work=The New York Times |first1=Greg |last1=Winter |first2=Alex |last2=Kuczynski |date=20 July 2000}}</ref>
In 2001, Ziff Davis Media Inc. reached an agreement with CNET Networks Inc. and ZDNet to regain the URLs lost in the 2000 sale of Ziff Davis Inc, to Softbank Corp.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_2001_Jan_23/ai_69405336/|title=Ziff Davis Media to Regain URLs |accessdate=2001-01-23 | work=Business Wire |year=2001}}</ref>
In 2002, CNET Networks launched ZDNet sister site Builder.com, a site intended for enterprise software developers.<ref>{{Cite web | title = CNET Networks Announces 'Builder.com,' Serving the Evolving Needs Of Enterprise Software Developers; New Site Goes 'Beyond the Code,' Offering Real-World Expertise to Help Developers Make High-Stakes Technology Decisions. | work = | publisher = CNET Networks | date = 18 March 2002 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/CNET+Networks+Announces+'Builder.com%2c'+Serving+the+Evolving+Needs+Of...-a083906577 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref> On July 7, 2002, CNET Networks acquired Newmediary for its database of more than 30,000 enterprise IT white papers.<ref>{{Cite web | title = CNET Networks Acquires Newmediary | work = | publisher = CNET Networks | date = 7 July 2002 | url = http://www.commonwealthvc.com/index.cfm/News/ArchivedNews/Archive_2002?NID=747 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref> ZDNet had integrated its services into its "Business & Technology" channel as early as January 2001.<ref>{{Cite web | title = ZDNet Launches Comprehensive Site for Government IT Professionals; Resource Serves ZDNet's Large Audience of Government Decision Makers with the News, Blogs, Whitepapers, Video, and Discussions They Care About. | work = | publisher = CNET Networks | date = 9 January 2001 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/ZDNet+Teams+With+Newmediary+to+Provide+Request+for+Proposal...-a068912288 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref>
====Realignment====
In 2003, CNET Networks redesigned and relaunched ZDNet as an enterprise-focused publication intended to help business executives make better technology decisions.
The entire site was realigned as part of a CNET Networks B2B portfolio that included CNET News.com, Builder.com and TechRepublic.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mediapost.com/publications/index.cfm?fa=Articles.showArticle&art_aid=16081|title=CNET Networks Re-launches ZDNet |accessdate=2003-02-17}}</ref>
A "Tech Update" section was created to serve as a directory of proprietary IT research (dubbed "IT Priorities"), and a new "Power Center" was implemented to prominently feature webcasts, white papers and case studies from partners. ZDNet also offered eight enterprise-targeted newsletters, as well launched its first blogs.<ref>{{Cite web | title = CNET Networks Re-launches ZDNet with Enterprise Buyer-Driven Content and Marketing Solutions. | work = | publisher = CNET Networks | date = 18 February 2003 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/CNET+Networks+Re-launches+ZDNet+with+Enterprise+Buyer-Driven+Content...-a097759480 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref>
In 2005, ZDNet Government was launched as the brand's first industry vertical, with a mission to cater to IT professionals in the public sector. Editorial features included writing by former Utah CIO Phil Windley, TechRepublic columnist Ramon Padilla and CNET News reporter Declan McCullagh. ZDNet also launched its first original podcasts in 2005.<ref>{{Cite web | title = ZDNet Launches Comprehensive Site for Government IT Professionals; Resource Serves ZDNet's Large Audience of Government Decision Makers with the News, Blogs, Whitepapers, Video, and Discussions They Care About. | work = | publisher = CNET Networks | date = 9 August 2005 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/ZDNet+Launches+Comprehensive+Site+for+Government+IT+Professionals%3b...-a0134966627 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref>
====ZDNet Blogs====
In 2006, ZDNet experienced another redesign that reduced its editorial focus on traditional news articles and product reviews and emphasized a growing network of expert bloggers, now totaling more than 30. The blogs covered topics such as enterprise IT, open source, Web 2.0, Google, Apple and Microsoft, and featured journalists David Berlind, Mary Jo Foley and Larry Dignan.<ref>{{Cite web | title = ZDNet Unveils the Next-Generation of Business Tech Publishing, Weaving Voice of Bloggers Around News, Product Reviews, Vendor and User Content. | work = | publisher = CNET Networks | date = 5 December 2006 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/ZDNet+Unveils+the+Next-Generation+of+Business+Tech+Publishing%2c...-a0155501890 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref>
On February 19, 2008, Larry Dignan was appointed editor-in-chief of ZDNet and editorial director of TechRepublic,<ref>{{Cite web | title = Larry Dignan Named Editor-in-Chief of ZDNet and Editorial Director of TechRepublic. | work = | publisher = CNET Networks | date = 19 February 2008 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Larry+Dignan+Named+Editor-in-Chief+of+ZDNet+and+Editorial+Director+of...-a0175041667 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref> replacing Dan Farber, who became editor-in-chief of CNET News.com.<ref>{{Cite web | title = Dan Farber Appointed Editor-in-Chief of CNET News.com. | work = | publisher = CNET Networks | date = 19 February 2008 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Dan+Farber+Appointed+Editor-in-Chief+of+CNET+News.com.-a0175041672 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref>
===The CBS years: 2008 to present===
On May 17, 2008, CBS Corporation announced that it would acquire CNET Networks for approximately $1.8 billion.<ref>{{Cite web | title = CNET sold to CBS for $1.8 billion. | work = | publisher = CBS Corporation | date = 17 May 2008 | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/CNET+sold+to+CBS+for+%241.8+billion.-a0181364984 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref> The entire company would be organized under its CBS Interactive division.
In May 2010, ZDNet redesigned its site to place emphasis on the topics its blog network covers—now "Companies," "Hardware," "Software," "Mobile," "Security" and "Research"—and de-emphasize the downloads and reviews it imported from CNET post-merger.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Dignan | first = Larry | title = ZDNet's redesign: A walkthrough | work = | publisher = CBS Interactive | date = 5 May 2010 | url = http://www.zdnet.com/blog/btl/zdnets-redesign-a-walkthrough/33119 | accessdate = 1 April 2010}} </ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://marcsdesign.com/blog/a-spring-refresh-for-zdnet/|title=A Spring refresh for ZDNet |accessdate=2010-08-05}}</ref>
==Content==
ZDNet currently operates a network of about 50 blogs loosely aligned by its major verticals: companies, hardware, software, mobile, security and IT research. Within those general areas are blogs on gadgets, management strategy, social media, datacenters, technology law, SOA, healthcare, CRM, virtualization and sustainability.
The site still offers product reviews and software downloads, which are mostly imported from CNET. It maintains an extensive database of enterprise-focused white papers.
==Awards and recognition==
At the 14th Annual Computer Press Awards in 1999, ZDNet was adjudged the Best Overall Online Site.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.computerpress.org/awards/awardwinners/14thpressrelease.html|title=Technology Journalists Honor the Best in Their Field|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref>
In 2007, the Association of Online Publishers awarded ZDNet UK under the Business Website category for its contribution to innovation in incorporating Web 2.0 and community features effectively on its site.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zdnet.co.uk/news/it-at-work/2007/10/04/zdnetcouk-wins-best-business-website-award-39289803/|title=ZDNet.co.uk Wins Best Business Website Award |accessdate=2007-04-10}}</ref>
==ZDNet international editions==
===ZDNet Japan=== A Japanese news publishing company called Asahi Interactive owns the ZDNet Japan website. According to alexa.com statistics, the Japan.zdnet.com subdomain is the second most visited on ZDNet, after the blogs subdomain. Also, the ZDNet website has an overall traffic rank of 558 in Japan.<ref name="alexa"/>
===ZDNet UK=== The ZDNet UK Live feature displays real time news updates and comments on the website and on social media including Twitter.
Other country editions include Australia, Asia, Belgium, China, Germany, Netherlands, UK and France, in their native languages.
